awd_titl_txt: SaTC: CORE: Medium: Collaborative: Understanding and Discovering Illicit Online Business Through Automatic Analysis of Online Text Traces
awd_abstract_narration:
Unlawful online business often leaves behind human-readable text traces for interacting with its targets (e.g., defrauding victims, advertising illicit products to intended customers) or coordinating among the criminals involved. Such text content is valuable for detecting various types of cybercrimes and understanding how they happen, the perpetrator's strategies, capabilities and infrastructures and even the ecosystem of the underground business.  Automatic discovery and analysis of such text traces, however, are challenging, due to their deceptive content that can easily blend into legitimate communication, and the criminal's extensive use of secret languages to hide their communication, even on public platforms (such as social media and forums). The project aims at systematically studying how to automatically discover such text traces and intelligently utilize them to fight against online crime. The research outcomes will contribute to more effective and timely control of online criminal activities, and the team's collaboration with industry also enables the team to get feedback and facilitate the transformation of new techniques to practical use. 
 
This project focuses on both criminals' communication with their targets and the underground communications among miscreants. To discover and understand illicit online activities, the research looks for any semantic inconsistency between text content and its context (such as advertisements for selling illegal drugs on an .edu domain) and for inappropriate operations being triggered (such as a malware download). Inconsistencies are captured by the Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques customized to various security settings. Further, based upon crime-related content discovered, the project will study various machine learning techniques that support automatic extraction and analysis of threat intelligence and criminal activities. The techniques are evaluated using data collected from various sources (public datasets, underground forums and others), and the findings they make are validated through a process that involves manual labeling, communication with affected parties, and collaborations with industry partners. This work will help create in-depth knowledge about underground ecosystems and lead to more effective control of illicit operations of these online businesses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to systematically study how to automatically discover semantic information embedded in cybercriminal activities and leverage it to better understand and combat online crimes. To this end, we developed advanced intelligent technologies, particularly those based on Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Machine Learning (ML). These technologies enable us to gain deeper insights into the cybercriminal ecosystem, their strategies, and capabilities, ultimately aiding in the detection, control, and mitigation of cyber threats.

Intellectual Merits. Throughout this project, we explored techniques to detect and interpret dark jargons—innocuous-looking terms like “popcorn” that cybercriminals widely use in communications for illicit activities such as drug transactions and crimeware exchanges. To analyze these coded terminologies, we employed semantic comparison models, projection learning, and masked language modeling on transformer-based architectures. In addition, we developed semantic-based techniques for gathering Cyber Threat Intelligence. A key advancement was the creation of an intelligent chatbot designed to autonomously identify and engage with real-world cybercriminals to gather e-commerce fraud artifacts.

Through the techniques developed in this project, we uncovered new cybercriminal activities and reconstructed holistic ecosystems from the cybercriminal  communication. Particularly, we investigated illicit drug listings using NLP and ML techniques. Our findings revealed that cybercriminals exploit problematic upstream local data brokers, which have weak control over data quality, to publish misleading business listings that promote illicit drug trade. This exploitation contaminates the knowledge bases of major search providers, leading to widespread dissemination of illicit content across web, map, and voice searches. Furthermore, by analyzing cross-platform interactions on social media, we developed automated comment analysis techniques to track the spread of illicit drug promotion through referral mechanisms across platforms. Our findings highlight the vulnerabilities in the local business listing ecosystem and its role in facilitating cybercrimes. Additionally, large language models (LLMs) are emerging as powerful tools, and are thus becoming prime targets for cybercriminals. To address this threat, we conducted the first systematic study on real-world LLMs used for malicious services (“Mallas”). Our findings on Malla have gained significant attention and have been widely covered by mainstream media.

To further understand the attack surfaces exploited by cybercriminals, we examined vulnerabilities in modern computing systems and their exploitation in cybercrime. Specifically,  we applied semantic analysis of public vulnerability reports to assess how cybercriminals leverage Internet-of-Things (IoT) vulnerabilities and developed defense mechanisms to mitigate these threats. We conducted the first comprehensive analysis of the mobile proxy ecosystem, which cybercriminals abuse to construct botnets and perpetrate advertisement fraud. We studied weaknesses in today’s Wikipedia system, demonstrating that NLP/ML techniques can be exploited to automatically generate stealthy revisions for black-hat search engine optimization (SEO), spreading illicit content through Wikipedia.

Broader Impacts. The findings of this project have been extensively disseminated at leading security, data science, and education venues. In addition, we developed a security knowledge service that extracts insights from malware research articles and released multiple datasets to support further research. These datasets cover illicit drug listings, manipulations on Wikipedia, abuses of LLMs, and more. Our research has also garnered widespread media coverage, including features in Le Monde, The Wall Street Journal, and other major outlets.

Beyond research contributions, we have actively integrated our findings into educational initiatives. This includes incorporating research outcomes into graduate-level courses, competitions, and summer internship programs. Particularly, through our summer internship program, we provided cybercrime defense training to students from Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs). These efforts not only advance cybercrime research but also foster diversity, collaboration, and educational opportunities in the field.

As part of our broader impact, we sought to raise awareness of cybercriminal activities and promote early STEM engagement by translating our research into accessible K-12 materials. A key initiative was the development of the illustrated book "Lorie in Cybersecurity Wonderland: The Fun of Camping & Mobile Security." In addition, we partnered with a local museum to host a K-6 Security Summer Camp and contributed to Indiana University’s pre-college cybersecurity immersion camp. These initiatives collectively broadened the reach and impact of our work, engaging young learners in cybersecurity education.


Last Modified: 01/30/2025
Modified by: Xiaojing Liao
